This is CS education.

I founded CSbyUs to be an undergraduate-led research group, guided by the belief that all students deserve to thrive in the digital age.
  • Funded by:
  • The Triangle Learning Network
  • Duke Bass Connections
  • The Holton Prize for Innovative Work in Education
  • Duke Gender, Sexuality, and Feminist Studies
  • Partnerships:
  • The North Carolina Department of Public Instruction
  • The NC State Friday Institute for Educational Innovation
  • Citizen Schools
  • Work presented at:
  • The National Service-Learning Conference
  • The IMPACT Conference
  • The All Things Open Conference
We used to be two students teaching after-school app development. Now we're designing North Carolina's first elementary CS curriculum.
Our interdisciplinary team partners with schools to co-design creative, equitable, and purposeful computer science learning experiences. To date, we have worked with 15+ partners, serving 200+ students.

Project-based learning, peer mentors, and self-transcendent goals are the principles undergirding our work.
Project-based learning

Projects are learning for the real world. With the opportunity to construct new knowledge and engage in real computer science practices, students can take their passions to new heights. To apply this theory, we have honed our curricula to focus on the design of mobile apps. Our students use the same design processes as engineers at Google, fusing new computer science principles with their prior passions, skills, and interests. The result is a future computer scientist, and a project to be proud of.

References:

  • Blumenfeld, P. C., Soloway, E., Marx, R. W., Krajcik, J. S., Guzdial, M., & Palincsar, A. (1991). Motivating Project-Based Learning: Sustaining the Doing, Supporting the Learning. Educational Psychologist, 26(3), 369.
  • Krajcik, J. S., & Shin, N. (2014). Project-based learning. In The Cambridge Handbook of the Learning Sciences (2nd ed., pp. 275–297). New York, NY: Cambridge University Press.
  • Van Horne, K., & Bell, P. (2017). Youth disciplinary identification during participation in contemporary project-based science investigations in school. Journal of the Learning Sciences, 26(3), 437–476.
Near-peer mentors

Peer relations are the water adolescents swim in. Classes that use these relationships to critique, encourage, and question students' work can nurture students' self-efficacy in computer science. To take advantage of these benefits, we design collaborative activities led by a new college student—an older peer mentor. We've found that our students doing projects with their peers are more likely to develop a sustained interest in computer science.

References:

  • Fields, D., & Enyedy, N. (2013). Picking Up the Mantle of “Expert”: Assigned Roles, Assertion of Identity, and Peer Recognition Within a Programming Class. Mind, Culture, and Activity, 20(2), 113–131.
  • Pon-Barry, H., Packard, B. W.-L., & John, A. S. (2017). Expanding capacity and promoting inclusion in introductory computer science: a focus on near-peer mentor preparation and code review. Computer Science Education, 27(1), 54–77.
  • Bandura, A. (1977). Self-efficacy: Toward a unifying theory of behavioral change. Psychological Review, 84(2), 191–215.
Self-transcendent goals

Self-transcendent goals help students discover their "why." When students can link their "why" to ideals like justice, family, and community, they persist through learning obstacles. To help our students persevere through frustration, we ask them to tie their projects to what they care about: reducing stress at school, protecting immigrant families, and making healthier food choices. We've come to believe that students should learn computer science not only for themselves, but for the people they care about.

References:

  • Yeager, D. S., Henderson, M. D., Paunesku, D., Walton, G. M., D’Mello, S., & Spitzer, B. J. (2014). Boring but Important: A Self-Transcendent Purpose for Learning Fosters Academic Self-Regulation. Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, 107(4), 559–580.
  • Vakil, S. (2014). A Critical Pedagogy Approach for Engaging Urban Youth in Mobile App Development in an After-School Program. Equity & Excellence in Education, 47(1), 31–45.
